While I think Mr. Eisenbrey's idea is a good one, I am still of the mind that, ultimately, what will make the most difference is federal-level legislation that binds all states. I also would caution against feeling too comfortable with current business practices, both in government and private industry, whose aims it is to circumvent the law. Many positions that, clearly, are not managerial in nature and, therefore, not exempt, are listed as such in order to prevent employees from earning overtime pay. The other thing I would like to remind everyone about is the fact that, since the start of the Great Recession, it is more common than not for workers to put in uncompensated overtime either at the work site or at home, for fear of losing their job.

Ultimately, it is going to take regulatory action to raise pay levels and a jobs bill to change the current work environment that millions of Americans work in. In a better economy, corporate cultures change, as do workers' attitudes.

As a 23 year-old who is currently in the process of quitting combustible cigarettes in favor of an electronic vaporization system, I wholeheartedly disagree with the notion that equal regulations for electronic cigarettes are desirable for public health.

In this day and age, it goes without saying that everyone accepts that smoking creates a much higher risk levels for deadly diseases. However, lung cancer and other fatal ailments are not a guarantee, for genetic reasons, and more importantly the rapid increases in medical technology (see nano.cancer.gov).

It may still be unwise in the eyes of many to continue smoking, but as someone who started smoking in the first place, it should go without saying that I am willing to accept relatively high levels of risk. Such a level of risk by itself would likely not have motivated me to quit (at least not for several more years).

However, the increasing degree of social unacceptability and hassle of going through long periods of time where I'm unable to smoke (i.e. air travel), combined with obvious health risk was sufficient to convince me to quit smoking cigarettes. I imagine that I'm not alone in making this semi-subconscious calculation.

There is no evidence to suggest e-cigs will be a gateway to real cigs, which I find more repulsive after vaping, and there is certainly no data showing second hand vapor is harmful. The benefits of limiting public e-cig use are vastly outweighed by the alternative: more smokers.

The studies will take time, and there will be no party deemed neutral enough to issue results trusted by both sides.

Accordingly, why choose to treat them as cigarettes now, instead of the other way around? After all, it's become unhip to judge others when there's no proof they are harming anyone but themselves. The simple answer seems to be that people want the power to excoriate others in public, and will not give that up unless they must.

Heck, pet dogs do more harm in NYC than e-cigarettes (street signs and mailboxes literally melt under their repeated attentions). Let's ban them instead!

there is no precedent for banning substances before they are proven harmful except of course marijuana. As someone who has struggled with nicotine addiction for almost 50 years, I can tell you the e-cig is a real blessing. I have used, patches, cold turkey, nicotine gum, chantix etc. I have quit 1 year twice, 2 years once, 3 years twice and 5 years twice. but always go back. My doctor recommended I try the ecig. What a blessing.
Should it be advertised, no that is unnecessary. Should it be regulated like combustible tobacco products, not unless you want to keep tobacco use high. Ecigs allow nicotine dosage control, for me reducing my nicotine intake and freeing me from Nicotine loading to comply with restricted places and times to smoke. Being free of this restriction, I reduce my intake automatically below what it was before, because I only intake enough to satisfy my craving without feeling I have to "finish that cigarette" whether I want it or not. I find that long periods of time pass before I have a craving. You can also control the amount of nicotine you are getting 18%, 11% or 5%, and flavor only 0% does, gradually reducing your nicotine intake making it easier to quit, The ecig has offered me the best chance of reducing the harm of cigarettes in my life, so please ecig opponents, go find another cause.

I'm undecided about the desirability of e-cigarette use.

I agree that e-cigarettes are a potentially effective tool for helping smokers to quit the habit. On the other hand, e-cigarettes could help to glamorize smoking and enhance its acceptability, especially among minors.

It is reasonable to conduct public health research on the pros and cons of e-cigarettes before determining their appropriate level of public usage. At present, however, it is premature to either extoll or excoriate the use of this product.

If immediate regulatory decisions are needed, I would support regulating e-cigarettes the same way that cigarettes are regulated, pending fuller understanding of their effects.

Our twin deficits, trade and budget, show that there is plenty of demand. We "demand" far more than we produce and the rising debt to pay for all that demand is a cancer sapping the strength from our economy.

Republicans demand--but never talk about demand. Their talking points scream confidence (voodoo!), deficits (shrinking), taxes (giant loopholes!)--but never wages, jobs, or demand--only ever increasing supply. A supply of capital which would be put through to the wealthy. Why?

Historically, countries have shown great resilience at absorbing job and wage increases. In the US with a $16%2B trillion economy, record profits, and record cash receipts, the tension between productivity and hoarding should yield to driving demand higher as productivity increases through adding jobs and increasing wages.

But what drives demand? It is the consumer--not business--that has lost confidence in business' ability to know. Balance sheets inspire greed, not dreams.

Amen. My husband is a salaried employee who works a minimum of 50 hours a week at a job classified as 37.5 hours, never takes all his sick leave or vacation time, and deals with texts and messages at home. He manages several people, has been a leader in implementing his department's new programs and technical overhauls, and interacts with the public—but is denied the dignity of a manager's title (because that would bring a substantial automatic salary increase), and after nearly 18 years in his workplace has only received petty COL raises despite sterling performance reviews. What's worse is that he actually receives less compensation now because he used to get perks like end-of-year reimbursement for vacation time not taken and free parking. Not to mention, of course, the bigger bite that health insurance is taking. (Moving is not an option for various reasons.)

Meanwhile, the head honcho gets a raise for next year that amounts to half my husband's annual salary. The raise isn't based on performance, but simply on the argument that people in her position make more elsewhere. In other words, a sense of entitlement rather than merit.

So the money's there. But without measures to compel fair compensation, those who wield power at the top will continue to hoard it.

It's so easy - in principle - to say: don't out give your information. But in reality, it's impossible NOT to: everyone, from department stores to dentists' offices, to on-line publications is in a business of mining our sensitive data - and 'sharing' (aka selling) without our knowledge or consent.

We need a law to rein in this appalling greed and protect our privacy. I'm tired of playing this game of giving out false e-mail addresses. Please, everyone who's read this article, do one useful thing today: share it with a friend. Sooner or later people will wake up, but let's try to speed up the awakening.

The first time I got asked for my zip code, I gave them a nearby one, not mine.  Unfortunately, they use the zip to confirm your credit card and mine didn't match so the transaction couldn't be processed.  I gave him my real one and the transaction went through.

We all have a right to say "no" when asked for this extra information.  When asked for an email address, birthdate, or phone number by a clerk, I decline.  I have provided my zip code to clerks, thinking it a harmless question, but I now understand it's not, and will give a fake one if pressed.  (I hold my ground on other personal data, too, writing "decline" on the social-security-number line of any non-financial form I am required to fill out.) If a store clerk pushes the point on the address or other information, ask to see a manager.  If they still demand that you provide information you don't want to provide -- information you are not required to share -- walk out of the store and take your business elsewhere.

Try this ... First we eliminate the pre-tax status of employer coverage. One way or another that money the company would have paid for insurance gets given to the employee. HSA or just wages.

Next we mandate catastrophic, i.e. major medical, insurance coverage by the head of household with subsidies, as needed, for the poor.

Next: a refundable tax credit for out of pocket medical care, and aim it away from insurance, say by a 20% credit on insurance and a 30% credit on direct payments. As a credit, it pays back even if the taxpayer's taxes due is less than $0.
Maybe even add some additional credits on anything over a certain amount of income.

Get the government, at all levels, out of the coverage mandates so a person can buy only the additional coverage (if any) they need or directly for the services they choose for themselves.

Who asks what something costs when it's paid by an insurance company or the government? When people are saving their own money, costs go down. Put people in charge of their own lives.

While this is just a quick outline, hopefully you can see what direction we need to go.

Oh ... And the claim that Obamacare was just implementing something proposed by the Heritage Foundation ... This is part of what they recommended.

Sex and reproduction require education and proactive planning. It is indeed unfortunate that over half of U.S. pregnancies are unplanned. To reduce that figure, I support:
--Sex education that addresses making an informed decision on whether or not to have sex, forms of birth control, circumstances that affect family planning, relevant state and federal laws on abortion rights, abortion methods, and deciding whether or not to have an abortion.
--Contraceptives and family planning services should be widely available.
--Ideally, abortion would be infrequent and rare, but it should be readily and widely available.
--Abstinence should be incorporated into the sex education curriculum as a viable personal choice.
